name: Geminid Meteor Shower Peak
description: Annual peak of the Geminid meteor shower, producing up to 120 meteors per hour under ideal conditions.
viewingTips: Find a dark location away from city lights. Allow 30 minutes for eyes to adjust. Look towards the constellation Gemini.

name: Full Cold Moon
description: The final full moon of 2024, traditionally called the Cold Moon by Native Americans.
viewingTips: Visible all night. Best viewed when high in the sky. Great opportunity for lunar photography.

name: Winter Solstice
description: Shortest day and longest night of the year in the Northern Hemisphere. Marks the official start of winter.
viewingTips: Ancient sites like Stonehenge align with the solstice sunrise. Many cultures celebrate this astronomical event.

name: Ursid Meteor Shower
description: Minor meteor shower radiating from Ursa Minor, producing 5-10 meteors per hour.
viewingTips: Look north towards the Little Dipper. Best viewing after midnight in dark sky locations.

name: Quadrantid Meteor Shower
description: One of the best meteor showers of the year with a brief but intense peak.
viewingTips: Peak lasts only a few hours. Bundle up and find a dark spot with clear northern sky view.

name: Mars at Opposition
description: Mars reaches opposition, appearing at its biggest and brightest in the night sky.
viewingTips: Mars will be visible all night. Excellent time for telescope viewing to see surface features and polar caps.

name: Venus-Jupiter Conjunction
description: Venus and Jupiter will appear extremely close together in the evening sky, separated by less than 1 degree.
viewingTips: Look west after sunset. The two brightest planets will appear as a stunning pair. Binoculars recommended.

name: Total Lunar Eclipse
description: Complete total lunar eclipse with the Moon passing through Earth's umbral shadow.
viewingTips: No special equipment needed. Find a location with clear eastern horizon. The Moon will turn reddish-orange during totality.

name: Lyrid Meteor Shower
description: One of the oldest known meteor showers, observed for over 2,600 years.
viewingTips: Dark skies help. The radiant is near the bright star Vega in the constellation Lyra.

name: Mercury at Greatest Elongation
description: Mercury reaches its greatest distance from the Sun in the evening sky, making it easier to spot.
viewingTips: Look low on the western horizon 30 minutes after sunset. Binoculars will help locate this elusive planet.
